user.biography: Since 1915, National Geographic Maps has been illustrating the world around us through the art and science of mapmaking. Visit NatGeoMaps.com.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Geographic Maps on August 06, 2021. May be an image of map.

node.text:
Published in April 1963 with the article "Sweden, Quiet Workshop of the World" this detailed look at the Nordic Region features subtle relief, ocean bathymetry and transportation routes including ferries. In the 1960's, and even today, many people from outside the region referred to it as "Scandinavia", named for the Scandinavian Peninsula that is shared by Norway, Sweden, and part of northern Finland. However, it is more appropriate to refer to it as the "Nordic Region" or "Nordic Countries", which includes all of Finland, Denmark, and Iceland, along with Norway and Sweden. All of these nations share Scandinavian roots and have seen their boundaries merge and split among themselves and with other nations through various conquests and treaties over the centuries.

Link to order map in bio

#scandinavia #nordic #nordicregion #scandinavian #map #norway #sweden #finland #iceland #denmark

node.text:
Published in February 1991 during the Gulf War, with a political map of the Middle East on the reverse side, this map of the Middle East highlights each country's military facilities, population, troops, oil reserves, gross national product, and more. The text provides an overview of the Gulf War, which was sparked by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait to seize the valuable oil reserves and coastline of its small but wealthy neighbor. 

Link to order map in bio

#middleeast #mideast #gulfwar #iraq #kuwait #iran #saudiarabia #oman #yemen #uae #qatar #jordan #syria #israel #egypt

node.text:
Published in April 1978, this travel map of the Canadian provinces of British Columbia, Alberta and the Yukon Territory shows hundreds of national parks, wilderness areas, campgrounds and ski resorts. It also highlights points of interest in cities such as Vancouver, Victoria, Edmonton, and Dawson. It represented an extension of the Close-Up USA series into Canada.

Link to order map in bio

#canada #britishcolumbia #alberta #yukon #canadian #provinces #vintagemaps #oldmaps #natgeomaps #natgeo #natgeomagazine #history #historical

node.text:
The "Reaches of New York City" map appeared in the April 1939 issue of National Geographic Magazine with articles about Long Island and 17th century explorer Henry Hudson. The decorative border is filled with illustrations of the famous people and sites of the New York region and references to the skyscraper architecture for which “The City” was famous.

Link to story in bio

#newyorkcity #newyork #nyc #hudsonvalley #antiquemaps #vintagemaps #oldmaps #natgeomaps #natgeo #natgeomagazine #history #historical

node.text:
Published first as a supplement in the January 1995 magazine, this educational map of the ancient monuments and landmarks of the Nile Valley provides an illustrated guide through Egypt’s ancient past, including a chronological legend indicating the period best represented by each site.

node.text:
Rainforests across the tropics, from Indonesia to Central America and from Madagascar to the jungles around the Mekong River, are being cut or burned—to make way for ranches, farms, and palm oil plantations, to be logged for wood or cleared for roads and other human development. Across the globe, up to 20 percent of tropical rainforests has been cleared just since the 1990s, while another 10 percent has been damaged as climate change brings higher temperatures, longer dry seasons, and more frequent droughts.

A team of top scientists, brought together by the National Geographic Society, with the support of Rolex, built an index to detect which forests need urgent help. The team combined 40 years of satellite data with other forest observations to create a “vulnerability index,” which scientists plan to use in coming years to track which stretches of tropical rainforest need help the most urgently.

Link to story in bio

#deforestation #rainforests #tropicalforests #habitatloss #climatechange #humanimpact #natgeo #nasajpl #rolex #perpetualplanet

node.text:
For nearly 600 years, Romans thrilled to gladiatorial fights. They were a favorite subject of Roman artists, re-created in mosaics, frescoes, marble reliefs, glassware, clay trinkets, and bronze ornaments found across the Roman world. Nearly every sizable city and town had an arena of its own, with about 300 documented from Britain to the deserts of Jordan, as shown in this map of gladiatorial venues. Archaeological research is shedding new light on gladiator combat and challenges the popular perception of these ancient spectacles. 

Link to NatGeo story in bio

#gladiators #romanhistory #ancientrome #natgeomagazine #natgeomaps #natgeo #maps

node.text:
Emperor Constantine had succeeded in reuniting the Roman Empire, but the empire soon divided into eastern and western halves. After converting to Christianity, Constantine left Rome for good and founded a city on the Bosporus in a.d. 330, calling it the New Rome. The city, later known as Constantinople, endured as the capital of the Byzantine Empire long after Rome and its western empire fell to Germanic invaders.

This map is from the World's Greatest Empires special publication bookazine.

Link to order bookazine in bio

#byzantine #empire #byzantineempire #natgeobooks #natgeomaps #bookazine

Published in February 1922 as a supplement to an issue of NatGeo magazine entirely devoted to "Middle America," this map of the Countries of the Caribbean includes inset maps of U.S. jurisdictions, steamship routes, and wireless stations in Central America, the West Indies, and Mexico.

node.text:
This Florida map was published in National Geographic Magazine in January 1930 with the article "Florida - The Fountain of Youth." Inset maps provide further detail in this early depiction of the Sunshine State. The Great Depression of the 1930's hit Florida hard, but the state came out of the economic malaise earlier than other parts of the U.S. thanks to the growth of tourism and aviation and many New Deal federal economic programs that benefitted the Miami area for decades. The 1930s was also the decade that brought Art Deco architecture to Miami Beach, still a key part of the city's character.

Link to order map in bio

#florida #floridahistory #maps #vintagemaps #natgeomaps #natgeo #natgeomagazine #miami

node.text:
Published in February 1914 with the article "The Nation's Undeveloped Resources," the Map of Alaska shows the growing human settlement of the remote region. U.S. public schools for natives, post offices, telegraph stations, mail routes, and mission stations are some of the many features shown on this map.

Link to order mp in bio

#alaska #alaskahistory #historicalmaps #antiquemaps #vintagemaps #natgeomaps #natgeo #natgeomagazine

node.text:
Roughly half of earth’s land has minimal human impact. A compilation of four methods for mapping human impact reveals in detail where humanity’s influence on the natural world is considered to be low. The map, published last June in the journal Global Change Biology, knits together four independently developed models for determining where humanity leaves its fingerprints, each using different indicators of activity.

All four models use human population, built-up areas, and cropland as inputs, but then they start to specialize. The Global Human Footprint index also uses roads, railway lines, navigable waterways, night-time lights, and pasturelands to identify the places where humankind is least noticeable.

The Anthropogenic Biomes project maps various kinds of populated ecosystems, like the “Residential Rangelands” of Africa, where pastoral people live in medium densities. The Global Human Modification and the Low Impact Areas maps are more recent attempts to identify where humans aren’t. Both include data on livestock density; the former also looks at mining and energy production and the latter includes data on protected areas and deforestation.

Researchers behind the various efforts decided to come together and see how well their maps overlapped; pretty well, it turns out.

Link to article in bio

#humanimpact #natureconservation #humanfootprint #wild #halfearth #conservation #natgeomaps #natgeo
